articles.headline: Without Notice, Putin Dissolves a News Agency
articles.snippet: The decision to dissolve RIA Novosti, along with its international radio broadcaster, came as a complete surprise and signaled a major state media reorganization in Russia.
articles.abstract: The decision to dissolve RIA Novosti, along with its international radio broadcaster, came as a complete surprise and signaled a major state media reorganization in Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin exerted new control over Russia’s state news media on Monday, dissolving by decree one of Russia’s official news agencies, RIA Novosti, along with its international radio broadcaster as he continues a drive to strengthen the Kremlin’s influence at home and abroad.

articles.headline: With Rental Demand Soaring, Poor Are Feeling Squeezed
articles.snippet: The problem of affordable rental housing has reached crisis proportions nationally, officials said on Monday.
articles.abstract: The problem of affordable rental housing has reached crisis proportions nationally, officials said on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Violeta Torres cannot afford her apartment.

articles.headline: Rule That Curbs Bank Risk-Taking Nears Approval
articles.snippet: Wall Street is entering an uncertain new era as the rule that has come to symbolize Washington’s efforts to rein in financial risk-taking finally takes hold.
articles.abstract: Wall Street is entering an uncertain new era as the rule that has come to symbolize Washington’s efforts to rein in financial risk-taking finally takes hold.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:44 p.m. | Wall Street is entering an uncertain new era as the rule that has come to symbolize Washington’s efforts to rein in financial risk-taking finally takes hold.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: If a Story Is Viral, Truth May Be Taking a Beating
articles.snippet: People post on Twitter or write stories for online news organizations like The Huffington Post or Gawker that spread quickly on the web as if factual, when they really aren’t.
articles.abstract: People post on Twitter or write stories for online news organizations like The Huffington Post or Gawker that spread quickly on the web as if factual, when they really aren’t.
articles.lead_paragraph: Truth has never been an essential ingredient of viral content on the Internet. But in the stepped-up competition for readers, digital news sites are increasingly blurring the line between fact and fiction, and saying that it is all part of doing business in the rough-and-tumble world of online journalism.
articles.byline: By Ravi Somaiya and Leslie Kaufman

articles.headline: How Mandela Shifted Views on Freedom of Markets
articles.snippet: Nelson Mandela’s extraordinary legacy of freedom overshadowed his complicated journey to support free markets and a free economy.
articles.abstract: Nelson Mandela’s extraordinary legacy of freedom overshadowed his complicated journey to support free markets and a free economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: When you think about Nelson Mandela, you probably think about freedom — free people, free country, free speech. What may be overshadowed by Mr. Mandela’s extraordinary legacy was his complicated journey to support free markets and a free economy.

articles.headline: Cerberus, Hamstrung in Efforts to Sell Firearm Maker, Tries New Tack
articles.snippet: Cerberus’s efforts to sell the company that produced the Bushmaster rifle used in the Sandy Hook shooting have been stymied by the public furor that prompted the auction in the first place.
articles.abstract: Cerberus’s efforts to sell the company that produced the Bushmaster rifle used in the Sandy Hook shooting have been stymied by the public furor that prompted the auction in the first place.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shortly after 1 a.m. on a day nearly a year ago, Cerberus Capital Management announced that it planned to sell its gun manufacturing company, the Freedom Group, after the deadly school shooting in Connecticut four days earlier.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: New G.M. Chief Is Company Woman, Born to It
articles.snippet: Mary T. Barra, who has spent 33 years with General Motors, completed a remarkable personal odyssey Tuesday when she was named as its next chief executive.
articles.abstract: Mary T. Barra, who has spent 33 years with General Motors, completed a remarkable personal odyssey Tuesday when she was named as its next chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Her father was a die maker for 39 years, one of the legions of employees who performed the gritty tasks that made General Motors the nation’s largest and most powerful auto company.

articles.headline: Police Push Into Kiev Square as Crisis Grows
articles.snippet: Security forces early Wednesday stormed the central plaza in Kiev where protesters have been rallying against the government of President Viktor F. Yanukovich.
articles.abstract: Security forces early Wednesday stormed the central plaza in Kiev where protesters have been rallying against the government of President Viktor F. Yanukovich.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Battalions of Ukrainian security forces early Wednesday stormed Independence Square, the central plaza in Kiev where protesters had been rallying against the government of President Viktor F. Yanukovich for more than two weeks.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: At the Finish Line on the Volcker Rule
articles.snippet: The so-called Volcker Rule, an effort to rein in risk-taking after the financial crisis, received approval after a laborious and contentious negotiation.
articles.abstract: The so-called Volcker Rule, an effort to rein in risk-taking after the financial crisis, received approval after a laborious and contentious negotiation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:02 p.m. | Five years after the financial crisis, President Obama summoned regulators to the White House for an update on how they were changing the ways of Wall Street.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Peter Eavis
